docs.lead_paragraph: GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI attributes New York's inability to balance its $105 billion budget largely to two problems: the exploding cost of providing health care services to the poor under its $44 billion Medicaid program and a court-ordered requirement to increase and equalize education spending by nearly $5 billion. But, as bad news often comes in threes, there's one more big-ticket item that few people are thinking about, and it may be as expensive: health insurance for the state's retired employees.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Governmental Accounting Standards Board member Cynthia Green maintains expensive health insurance provided to state's retired employees is another reason why New York Gov George Pataki is unable to balance budget; notes state will be required in 2008 to publicly disclose for first time full cost and liabilities related to providing such health benefits (M)
docs.snippet: New York needs to figure out how to finance the high cost of health insurance for its retired workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Laura Suzanne Bernstein, a daughter of Amy and Roy J. Bernstein of New York, was married last evening to James Joseph O'Hare IV, the son of James Joseph O'Hare III of Hingham, Mass., and the late Karen Morris O'Hare. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated at the Essex House in New York. The couple graduated from Trinity College in Hartford, where they met.

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Motors Corporation has decided its employee health plans will largely stop covering prescriptions filled at Walgreen drugstores. The two companies have been at odds since last year, when G.M. began requiring employees to buy drugs for chronic conditions like high cholesterol through the mail. Such arrangements hurt pharmacies like Walgreen but save money for employers like G.M., which has said the mail-order program could cut its prescription drug costs by $80 million a year. Walgreen has strongly opposed the shift to mail order, and in 2003 said it would not sign new contracts with companies that have mandatory mail-order drug policies for their employees. Fearing that Walgreen would drop it as a customer, G.M. decided to stop doing business with Walgreen as a pre-emptive measure. A Walgreen spokesman, Michael Polzin, said G.M.'s decision came as a surprise Jeremy W. Peters (NYT)

headline.main: G.M. ENDS PRESCRIPTION DEAL WITH WALGREEN

docs.abstract: General Motors Corp, in pre-emptive move, decides its employee health plans will largely stop covering prescriptions filled at Walgreen drugstores; Walgreen has said it would not sign new contracts with companies that have mandatory mail-order drug policies covering chronic conditions (S)
docs.snippet: The General Motors Corporation has decided its employee health plans will largely stop covering prescriptions filled at Walgreen drugstores. The two companies have been at odds since last year, when G.M. began requiring employees to buy drugs for...

docs.lead_paragraph: It may sound shrill to describe President Bush as someone who takes food from the mouths of babes and gives the proceeds to his millionaire friends. Yet his latest budget proposal is top-down class warfare in action. And it offers the Democrats an opportunity, if they're willing to take it. First, the facts: the budget proposal really does take food from the mouths of babes. One of the proposed spending cuts would make it harder for working families with children to receive food stamps, terminating aid for about 300,000 people. Another would deny child care assistance to about 300,000 children, again in low-income working families.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says Pres Bush's budget really does shower largess on millionaires even as it punishes the needy; calls his latest budget proposal top-down class warfare; says question is whether relentless mean-spiritedness of his budget finally awakens public to true cost of his tax policy; questions why affluent, who have done so well from Bush's policies, should not pay part of price of dealing with problem of budget deficit; hopes Democrats push back against Bush's tax policy (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush's latest budget proposal is top-down class warfare in action. And it offers the Democrats an opportunity, if they're willing to take it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Calls to the city's 311 line soared 86 percent last summer, largely because of people seeking information about property tax rebates and garbage pickups or filing noise complaints, according to data released yesterday. The increase has put a strain on agencies that deal with those issues, city officials said. During the first four months of the fiscal year that started on July 1, New Yorkers made 328,000 calls asking about the $400 rebate offered to homeowners last year. Those inquiries accounted for the largest source of calls to 311 in that period, followed by 165,000 calls related to sanitation and 127,000 noise complaints.

headline.main: Report on City Is Positive, But It Notes Some Strains

docs.abstract: Preliminary Mayor's Management Report, early look at annual report card on city government performance and trends, paints generally sunny picture; details noted; graph shows subjects of callers to 311 help line (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN politics, success can come as much from framing the terms of the debate as from winning the debate. In that sense, President Bush has scored early victories in the budget battle even as some of his specific plans to cut spending have been criticized. Nearly all the attention on the budget was focused on the spending side, which is just where the president would prefer it to be, even if that did mean a lot of talk about the fact that budget projections ignored the costs of his Social Security proposals. The tax side of the budget, which the administration calculates would cost $1.4 trillion from 2006 through 2015, has been virtually ignored.

headline.main: Games Politicians Play: More Tax Cuts as U.S. Faces Large Deficits

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris column on US budget deficits focuses on tax side of budget, which Bush administration calculates would cost $1.4 trillion from 2006 through 2015; says one area that deserves attention is estate tax; says law calls for phasing out that tax and then bringing it back; holds estate tax provision costs $256 billion; says more could be saved by stopping process of reducing tax every year; graph (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush has scored early victories in the budget battle even as some of his specific plans to cut spending have been criticized.

docs.lead_paragraph: At times, it is necessary to ''neutralize'' the opposition, or at least Merck & Company executives seemed to think so. In 1999, the company's new pain drug, Vioxx, was beaten to pharmacy shelves by a competing drug, Celebrex. Merck apparently hoped that nationally known rheumatologists like Dr. Roy Altman could help it catch up.

headline.main: Marketing of Vioxx: How Merck Played Game of Catch-Up

docs.abstract: Internal company documents illustrate Merck & Co's long-running campaign to enlist support of doctors for Vioxx, its pain drug, or to 'neutralize' their support for competing drug Celebrex; drug companies routinely try to woo doctors to prescribe or promote their drugs, but internal Merck documents offer rare, behind-the-scenes look into extremes of this process--one that may have blurred line between legitimate promotion and offering inducements to doctors to prescribe drug; show Merck officials planned to offer clinical trials, posts as consultants or grants to doctors; Merck sought out nationally known rheumatologists like Dr Roy Altman to support Vioxx, and put up $25,000 to fund clinical trial Altman wanted to run; one internal Merck document has words 'show me the money' near Altman's name; Altman says his involvement in trial did not affect his prescribing; federal investigators, state officials, Congressional committees and lawyers for plaintiffs have obtained thousands of internal Merck documents while pursuing investigations and lawsuits related to Vioxx; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Merck staged a long-running campaign to enlist the support of doctors for Vioxx, to "neutralize" them, as documents put it.

byline.original: By BARRY MEIER and STEPHANIE SAUL

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the health insurance company, said yesterday that its profit rose 21 percent in the fourth quarter and that it increased its forecast for 2005, helped by better-than-expected membership enrollment. The company, which also set a 2-for-1 stock split and doubled its dividend, said medical membership grew 5 percent, to 13.7 million. Fourth-quarter net income rose to $300.7 million, or $1.95 a share, from $249.5 million, or $1.56 a share, a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, the company, based in Hartford, earned $1.82 a share in the latest quarter, better than the $1.79 expected by analysts. Revenue rose 13 percent, to $5.2 billion, driven by an increase of 86,000 in medical membership.

headline.main: AETNA RAISES OUTLOOK FOR YEAR AS PROFIT RISES 21%

docs.abstract: Aetna says profit rose 21 percent in fourth quarter; net income rose to $300.7 million from $249.5 million year earlier; revenue increased 13 percent, to $5.2 billion; company increases its forecast for 2005, sets 2-for-1 stock split and doubles its dividend (S)
